item.title: This May Be Our Last Chance to Get It Right in Venezuela
item.description: For the past decade, every administration in Washington has said Venezuela represents an extraordinary threat to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jimmy Story

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times

item.title: Myanmar’s Health Crisis Spills Over Borders
item.description: Fighting has caused the spread of illnesses like malaria and cholera. In a worst-case scenario, the situation could threaten regional health security, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl and Lauren DeCicca

media:content.media:description: People wait at the Mae Tao Clinic in Thailand near the Burmese border. The number of patients has soared after a coup in Myanmar ignited a civil war.

item.description: Crossing over from Myanmar into Mae Sot, Thailand, by boat one December morning.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Estonia’s Star-Spangled Courting of Capitol Hill
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 26, 2025.

item.title: From Designing Clothes for Children to a Wedding of Bows and Tinsel
item.description: Susanna Treacy and Nicholas Wiegand, who were both designers at babyGap, saw their casual elevator chats at work slowly turn into more after an unexpected night out in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Block

item.title: From Cuddling to Cold Shoulder and Back Again (and Again)
item.description: We talked about our ideal wedding on our third date. That was probably too soon.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Perkins

item.title: From the Shadows to Power: How the Hindu Right Reshaped India
item.description: The far-right group known as the R.S.S., whose members include Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has spent a century trying to make India a Hindu-first nation.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke

media:content.media:description: R.S.S. volunteers listening to chief Mohan Bhagwat’s speech at the centenary celebration in Nagpur, India, in October.

item.title: He Asked for Five More Dates Before the First One Ended
item.description: A long-distance start and a fateful coincidence led Brandon Begin, a BMX rider, and Sara Crisman to wedding celebrations in Paris and New York.
item.dc:creator: Donna Kim

item.description: R.S.S. volunteers performing at the organization’s centenary celebrations.

media:content.media:description: RSS Swayamsevaks (volunteers) at 100 yrs of RSS event on Vijay dashmi day at Reshimbag, Nagpur, India on 2 October 2025.

item.description: Supporters shouting slogans at R.S.S. volunteers while they march through the streets of Nagpur.
A ceremony in Nagpur to celebrate the first two leaders of the R.S.S.
Raising the R.S.S. flag.

media:content.media:description: RSS Swayamsevaks (volunteers) at the early morning Shakha at the local community park in Nagpur, India on 3 October 2025.

item.title: They Matched Twice. The Second Time Changed Everything.
item.description: Rich Ferraro wasn’t sure that marriage was for him until he matched with David Mansur — and rediscovered a screenshot from their first match two years earlier.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: 5 Key Moments in the Rise of India’s Hindu-First Powerhouse
item.description: The Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, known as the R.S.S., has survived bans and vilification to emerge as the force reshaping India’s secular republic into a Hindu nation.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar

media:content.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: R.S.S. volunteers at a centenary celebration event in Nagpur in October.

item.title: Death Toll in UPS Plane Crash Rises to 15
item.description: Alain Rodriguez Colina, who was injured when a cargo plane crashed into his Kentucky workplace more than a month ago, died on Christmas Day.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:description: Officials in Kentucky said a 15th victim of the UPS plane crash in Louisville died on Thursday.

item.title: NYT Crossword Hints for Dec. 26, 2025
item.description: Andrew Spooner makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
item.dc:creator: Deb Amlen

media:content.media:description: Andrew Spooner’s debut puzzle will warm up your brain for the tough Saturday crossword ahead.

item.title: Trump Administration Emphasizes Religion in Official Christmas Messages
item.description: Government officials have traditionally steered clear of such overtly religious language, as the Constitution prohibits the establishment of an official state religion.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump while making Christmas calls to children at Mar-a-Lago on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Strikes ISIS in Nigeria After Trump Warned of Attacks on Christians
item.description: The attack comes after President Trump ordered the Defense Department last month to prepare to intervene militarily in Nigeria to protect Christians from Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Saikou Jammeh and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:description: Gunmen attacked the Christ Apostolic Church in Kwara State, Nigeria, in November.

item.title: Judge Blocks Detention of British Researcher Who Scrutinizes Online Hate
item.description: Imran Ahmed, who runs an organization that chronicles disinformation, was among five Europeans the State Department had barred, claiming they promote censorship.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi

media:content.media:description: Imran Ahmed, the chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, in Miami this year.

item.title: The Biggest Moments of Trump’s 2025: Mass Deportations, Tariffs and More
item.description: Here are some of the most consequential, illuminating or just plain remarkable moments from Donald Trump’s first year back in the White House.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Journey to Antarctica Part 3
item.description: What do you pack for a two-month expedition to Antarctica? Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong shows us what he is bringing along for his journey.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Christina Shaman, Jon Miller, Leila Medina, Edward Vega, Stephanie Swart and Rebecca Suner

item.title: En su discurso de Navidad, el papa León exhorta a los líderes mundiales al diálogo
item.description: El discurso de Navidad de León XIV es el primero desde su elección como pontífice, y fue objeto de escrutinio en busca de comparaciones con los de su predecesor, Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

media:content.media:description: El papa León XIV saluda a la multitud congregada en el Vaticano el día de Navidad.

item.title: Elecciones en Honduras: un candidato presidencial alega fraude
item.description: Luego de que las autoridades declararan ganador de la contienda a Nasry Asfura, su rival respaldado por Trump, Salvador Nasralla cuestionó el resultado y expresó fastidio por el papel desempeñado de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jeff Ernst

media:content.media:description: Nasry Asfura en Tegucigalpa, Honduras, el mes pasado.

item.title: Remembering Those Who Died This Year
item.description: We look back at the lives of some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Sara Hirakawa for The New York Times; Michael Christopher Brown; Norman Seeff; Ornstein Family

item.title: New York City Braces for Heavy Snow as Winter Storm Approaches
item.description: The region could see accumulations of up to 5 to 7 inches from late Friday into Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro

media:content.media:description: New York City got a bit of snow earlier in December. On Friday and Saturday, the city is expecting a more significant accumulation.

item.title: Where to Eat Like You’re on ‘30 Rock’ and More Reader Questions
item.description: Becky Hughes’ monthly advice column is back with hyper-specific answers to your hyper-specific queries.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes

media:content.media:credit: Heather Willensky for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: It’s no Lover’s Delight, but the chocolate cake at Carne Mare comes pretty close.

item.title: John Carey, Literary Eminence Who Excoriated Snobbery, Dies at 91
item.description: An Oxford professor and renowned critic, he was pugnacious, fearless and disdainful of the received wisdom of his intellectual milieu.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Robert Lindsey, Times Reporter and Reagan Ghostwriter, Dies at 90
item.description: The nonfiction spy thriller “The Falcon and the Snowman,” which became a film, grew out of his work as a journalist covering the West Coast for The Times.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

media:content.media:description: Robert Lindsey in 1979, when he was the Los Angeles bureau chief for The New York Times.

item.title: Five Killed in Helicopter Crash on Kilimanjaro, Africa’s Highest Peak
item.description: The aircraft was on its descent from the mountain when it crashed around the Barafu Camp area in Kilimanjaro National Park, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Brian Otieno

media:content.media:description: The snow-capped Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania, as seen from Kimana, Kenya. The Tanzanian authorities were making arrangements with the relevant embassies to return the bodies of those killed in the crash.

item.title: The 10 Most Popular Meatless NYT Cooking Recipes of 2025
item.description: Porcini ragù. Roasted broccoli with whipped tofu. French lentil salad. Here’s what readers loved the most.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.
media:content.media:description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s hoisin garlic noodles.

item.title: Kimmel Tells U.K. Viewers ‘Tyranny Is Booming’ in America
item.description: Chosen by a British TV station to give an “alternative” to the king’s speech, Jimmy Kimmel said it had been a great year for the U.S. “from a fascism perspective.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden

media:content.media:description: A photograph released by Channel 4 for Jimmy’s Kimmel’s “Alternative Christmas Message.”

item.title: Honduran Candidate Claims Fraud After Trump-Backed Opponent Is Declared Victor
item.description: After officials called the presidential race for Nasry Asfura, his rival, Salvador Nasralla, disputed the result and expressed ire over the U.S. role.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jeff Ernst

media:content.media:description: Nasry Asfura in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, last month.

item.title: No Power, No Heat, No Water: Odesa’s Days of Hell Under Russian Fire
item.description: The toll on older people and those with disabilities is especially severe as Moscow’s forces repeatedly attack the port city’s infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn and Laetitia Vançon

media:content.media:description: Distributing hot meals to those affected by power outages in Odesa last week.

item.title: Berry Jam Buns
item.description: A filling made from berry preserves and fresh berries replaces the buttery cinnamon sugar you might expect in a cinnamon roll, for a colorful twist on a favorite.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Cooking

item.title: Prominent Leaders Amplify Disinformation About Brown University Shooting
item.description: Prominent business and government figures spread rumors about the attack on Brown University’s campus this month, reigniting questions about accountability in online discourse.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial outside the Van Wickle Gates on the Brown University campus, where a mass shooting killed two people.

item.title: No Power, No Heat, No Water: Odesa’s Days of Hell Under Russian Fire
item.description: The toll on older people and those with disabilities is especially severe as Moscow’s forces repeatedly attack the port city’s infrastructure.

media:content.media:credit: Laetitia Vançon for The New York Times

item.title: El espacio aéreo cerrado trajo una Navidad solitaria para muchos en Venezuela
item.description: Durante las festividades, un gran número de venezolanos de la diáspora suele regresar a casa. Pero este año, después de que las líneas aéreas internacionales interrumpieran casi todos sus servicios, muchas personas están solas y con los nervios de punta.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: La mayoría de los vuelos extranjeros que entran y salen del Aeropuerto Internacional Simón Bolívar, el principal aeropuerto de la capital venezolana, Caracas, han sido cancelados.

item.title: Sweet-Salty Popcorn and Peanuts for Christmas Snacking

media:content.media:credit: Kelly Marshall for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Roscoe Betsill. Prop Stylist: Sarah Smart.
media:content.media:description: Yewande Komolafe’s gúgúrú àti epà (sweet-salty popcorn and peanuts).

item.title: Trump Has a New Auto Loan Tax Break. Here’s Who Could Benefit.
item.description: Many Americans can take advantage of President Trump’s deduction on auto loan interest, but the tax break will provide only modest savings.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

media:content.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An auto loan deduction comes at a time when the industry is struggling to adapt to President Trump’s tariffs.

item.title: Estonia’s Man on Capitol Hill Is on a Charm Offensive
item.description: The Baltic nation’s congressional liaison is using candy, an American flag outfit and “Die Hard” jokes to make friends in Congress as the Trump administration turns against Europe.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In his time in Washington, Karl-Gerhard Lille has helped recruit more than 70 representatives and about a dozen senators to the Baltic Caucus, with many joining this year.

item.title: King Charles Urges ‘Compassion’ and Finding Strength in Diversity in Annual Christmas Message
item.description: His annual Christmas message was more outward-looking than last year’s, when he focused on the medical workers who had helped him and his daughter-in-law after their cancer diagnoses.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla arriving at St. Mary Magdalene Church in Sandringham, England, on Thursday for a Christmas Day service.

item.title: Christmas Around the World in Photos
item.description: The holiday spirit is bringing people together, with celebrations of lights, dance and Santa.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:description: A Christmas Eve service at the Syriac Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Basra, Iraq.

item.title: Win A Reporting Trip with Nicholas Kristof
item.description: Every year columnist Nicholas Kristof chooses a university student to accompany him on a “win-a-trip” reporting journey.

item.title: Pope Leo Makes Christmas Call for Dialogue to Address World’s Conflicts
item.description: Leo XIV’s Christmas address was his first since being elected pontiff and was scrutinized for comparisons with those of his predecessor, Francis.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV greeting the crowd gathered at the Vatican on Christmas Day.

item.description: Readers reflect on a column by David French on religious belief. Also, A Trump order bullies states on A.I.
